definition: Composed of the brain and spinal cord, it processes and integrates sensory data and coordinates motor output.
A fluid that cushions the CNS, circulates nutrients, and removes waste. Produced by choroid plexuses in the ventricles.
The tough, outermost meningeal layer that provides structural support and protection for the brain and spinal cord.
The middle meningeal layer, web-like in structure, containing the subarachnoid space where CSF circulates.
The delicate innermost layer of the meninges, closely adhering to the surface of the brain and spinal cord, containing blood vessels.
A fold of dura mater that separates the cerebral hemispheres.
Capillary networks in ventricles that produce cerebrospinal fluid by filtering blood plasma.
A CSF-filled cavity located between the brainstem and cerebellum, continuous with the central canal of the spinal cord.
Receptor, sensory neuron, interneuron, motor neuron, and effector involved in reflex responses.
A protective reflex that causes withdrawal from a painful stimulus.
A reflex where one limb withdraws while the opposite limb extends to maintain balance.
The simultaneous activation of one muscle group and inhibition of its antagonist to coordinate movement.
A reflex that tests the C7-C8 nerves, causing contraction of the triceps brachii muscle.
A sensory pathway transmitting pain, temperature, and crude touch to the thalamus.

term: Gray Matter of the Spinal Cord
definition: Contains neuronal cell bodies and interneurons involved in processing and integrating sensory and motor signals.
A major nerve in the brachial plexus that innervates the hand and forearm.
Supplies the deltoid and teres minor muscles and the skin over the shoulder.
Innervates the adductor muscles of the thigh and part of the skin on the medial thigh.
A bundle of nerve roots extending from the lower spinal cord resembling a horse's tail.
An enlarged area of the spinal cord that supplies nerves to the upper limbs.
The largest brain region responsible for sensory perception, voluntary movements, learning, memory, and higher reasoning.
Connects the brain to the spinal cord and controls basic life functions like breathing, heartbeat, and reflexes.
Responsible for coordination of voluntary movements, balance, and posture.
A thick band of axons that connects and facilitates communication between the two cerebral hemispheres.
Involved in voluntary movement, decision-making, reasoning, and speech production (Broca's area).
Processes sensory input related to touch, temperature, and body position.
Processes auditory information, memory, and language comprehension (Wernicke's area).
The brain's primary visual processing center.
Subcortical gray matter structures that regulate voluntary movement by inhibiting or facilitating motor commands.
A network of structures involved in emotion, motivation, and memory processing.
Contains the thalamus and hypothalamus; relays sensory information and regulates homeostasis.
Regulates temperature, thirst, hunger, sleep, and links the endocrine and nervous systems.
The primary somatosensory cortex located in the parietal lobe, processing sensory input from the body.
Neurons in the cerebral cortex responsible for voluntary motor control.
The outer layer of gray matter in the cerebrum responsible for higher mental processes.
One hemisphere (typically the left) dominates functions like language, writing, and analytical tasks.
Helps regulate movement initiation and prevent unwanted movements.
Contain motor, sensory, and autonomic fibers.
An area of skin innervated by a single spinal nerve.
Controls voluntary movements by innervating skeletal muscles.
Regulates involuntary functions such as heart rate and digestion.
Prepares the body for fight or flight responses, increasing heart rate and energy mobilization.
Promotes rest and digest activities, decreasing heart rate and conserving energy.
Characteristic of the parasympathetic nervous system; extend to ganglia near target organs.
Transmit visual information from the retina to the brain.
Control most eye movements, pupil constriction, and maintaining an open eyelid.
Control facial expressions, taste from the anterior tongue, and salivary/lacrimal glands.
Controls autonomic functions in the heart, lungs, and digestive tract.
Pressure-sensitive receptors that detect changes in blood pressure.
Specialized cells in the retina (rods and cones) that detect light.
The decrease in sensitivity to a constant stimulus over time.
Respond to physical deformation such as pressure, vibration, and stretch.
Receptors in muscles that detect stretch and initiate reflexes to resist it.
Receptors in tendons that protect against excessive tension.
The sense of head position relative to gravity, detected by the vestibule in the inner ear.
Detect rotational movements of the head for dynamic equilibrium.
The light-sensitive layer of the eye where images are focused and converted into neural signals.
The region of the retina with the highest visual acuity, densely packed with cones.
A visual defect caused by an irregularly shaped cornea or lens.
Bundles of axons in the midbrain that connect the cerebrum to the lower parts of the brain and spinal cord.
Part of the midbrain involved in visual reflexes, such as tracking moving objects.
Part of the midbrain responsible for auditory reflexes, such as the startle response to loud sounds.
A network of interconnected neurons in the brainstem that regulates wakefulness and sleep-wake transitions.
The area between the arachnoid mater and pia mater filled with cerebrospinal fluid.
A selective barrier formed by endothelial cells that prevents harmful substances in the bloodstream from entering the brain.
The brain's relay center for sensory information (except smell), directing it to the appropriate areas of the cerebral cortex.
Part of the brainstem that controls vital functions such as heartbeat, breathing, and blood pressure.
A part of the brainstem that relays signals between the medulla and the cerebellum, and also contains centers that regulate respiration.
Fiber tracts connecting the cerebellum to the brainstem, facilitating communication and coordination.
A brain region in the temporal lobe involved in language comprehension.
A brain region in the frontal lobe responsible for speech production and articulation.
Regions of the cerebral cortex that integrate sensory and motor information and are involved in higher cognitive processes.
Controls most of the eye's movements, the constriction of the pupil, and maintains an open eyelid.
Controls facial expressions, taste sensations from the anterior tongue, and salivary and tear gland functions.
Controls swallowing, taste from the posterior tongue, and monitors blood pressure and oxygen levels in the blood.
Controls tongue movements essential for speech and swallowing.
Projections of the arachnoid mater into dural sinuses that allow for the reabsorption of cerebrospinal fluid into the bloodstream.
A small endocrine gland in the brain responsible for producing melatonin, regulating sleep-wake cycles.
The specialization of certain functions, such as language (left hemisphere) or spatial abilities (right hemisphere), in one hemisphere of the brain.
Pain perceived in a location different from the actual source due to shared nerve pathways.
Pathways in the spinal cord that carry sensory information to the brain.
Pathways in the spinal cord that transmit motor commands from the brain to the body.
The crossing of motor fibers in the medulla, which explains why each brain hemisphere controls the opposite side of the body.
The body's ability to sense its position and movement in space through receptors in muscles, tendons, and joints.
A midbrain structure involved in reward, addiction, and movement, with dysfunction linked to Parkinson's disease.
Processes odor information from the olfactory nerves and relays it to the brain.
The central region of the cerebellum involved in regulating posture and locomotion.
The ability of the brain to reorganize itself by forming new neural connections throughout life.
A part of the limbic system critical for the formation and retrieval of memories.
A limbic structure involved in emotional responses, particularly fear and aggression.
